reviewText:
A bit of a warning, this will be my rantiest review I think I've ever done.

Let me start off by politely, and courteously, taking a moment to ask why, out of every Silent Hill game, is this the only one on Steam? Now don't get me wrong, I'll get to Homecoming in a moment, but as most other entries in the series had PC ports, why. biased Konami, is this the only one Steam gets?

With that out of the way, Silent Hill Homecoming is the sixth main entry in the SH series, a psychological survival-horror series that has come to be known best for its atmosphere, story, surrealism, and creepy monster designs.

Silent Hill Homecoming came out on the heels of the Silent Hill film, and it shows. Several monster designs and much of the visual look of the game can be attributed to the film. Most notably, the game has some impressive Otherworld transition sequences inspired by the movies. They look cool, and sound cool, so they at least get the job done there.

And that's something to be said for Homecoming. It's not a terrible looking game, the designs of the characters and monsters at least look cool, the environments look appropriately ominous, and the fog effects, while a bit sparser than other entries in the series, are still rather well-handled.

However, the film inspiration becomes a bit much in areas. This was the game that shoe-horned Pyramid Head in for no reason, and I literally mean no reason. Oh, he appears in cutscenes, but not a single time in gameplay. Not once. And that's not even arguing on how he has no reason to be here. Both in the fact he literally does nothing in the story and it goes against on what Pyramid Head was in SH2. And then there's scenes that were so obviously inspired by the movie, and enemies inspired by the movie. It essentially is an extension to the Silent Hill movie in game form, honestly.

But so much goes against what the SH series is. I was literally in hysterics during a scene almost half-way in the game when suddenly you get a sassy black sidekick comic relief character and escape a police station being invaded Dawn of the Dead style by giant hammerhead land-shark monsters. Don't get me wrong, this is brilliant B-Movie hamminess, but what the ♥♥♥♥ is it doing in the ♥♥♥♥ing Silent Hill series?

And that's what I think one of Homecoming's biggest problems is. It doesn't know what the SH series is. I am convinced the creators just watched the SH movie and made the game based off of that. There's no other explanation for it. Homecoming must of at one point in development been a video game adaption of the movie, because it has so much in common with the film; the nurses work just like they do in the film, so does the cult, and the aesthetics... But it's almost nothing like how the rest of the series is.

But let's get off our fixations of its identity crisis and focus more on the game as its own experience.

Silent Hill Homecoming tells the story of a man named Alex Sheppard who's returning from the military to visit his home in Sheppard's Glen (of course conveniently named after his family). He's been gone for a long time and finds that his hometown has completely changed. There's a few people still living in town, but the place is mostly deserted. Alex comes home to find his brother and father are missing, and his mom seems completely out of it with a pistol on her lap. Alex goes to investigate what exactly has happened to his family, and to this town, and what sort of connection it has with the nearby local resort town of Silent Hill.

To the story's credit, I did end up liking a few of the characters, most notably Alex, who did end up earning some sympathy from me through his journey. And Wheeler, your sassy black comedy relief character, was enjoyable, though so out of place. Most everyone else was forgettable, however. The plot twists unfortunately are mostly super predictable, the worst of all being the 'main' twist, and while I don't want to spoil the game, towards the end we get into some ludicrous Saw-inspired segments that just feel completely out of left field and unneeded. Homecoming also holds my personal honor for having the worst multiple endings I have ever experienced in a horror game. I'm not kidding, they are that bad.

The game has a few puzzles, and by puzzles I mean over half of them are sliding tile puzzles or this puzzle about crossing wires. Whoever the ♥♥♥♥ at Double Helix thought that making most of the puzzles in the game ♥♥♥♥ing sliding puzzles really deserves a solid kick in the ♥♥♥.

The game is also overly focused on combat. The combat to be fair isn't bad, with a very Zelda-esque system, being able to lock-onto enemies and circle and roll-dodge from them, but the weapons are notably unbalanced with some being far better than others. Also while technically the 'best' combat system in the series (and they try to rationalize it with the fact Alex is an ex-soldier), the series was never really about the combat, making it feel like the developers missed the point.

Also the PC port is a hit or miss based on your system. It either works perfectly fine, or it doesn't. Fans have made a lot of work-arounds for problems in the game, but it has had absolutely no official support. It was basically released on Steam, and left to die there.

This so far makes it sound like I hate Homecoming, but in earnest I didn't.

Homecoming has so much wrong with it, as a Silent Hill game, as a horror game, and as an action game, that it's easy to mention, but it's actually not a terrible game, and has several quite good moments and actually is an okay to good game, though I'd argue one of the weakest in its series.

Homecoming has some decent moments. Exploring the house is both interesting and a bit haunting. Going into the basement the first time is a bit unnerving. A few of the boss fights, especially the second one, are actually well-done. The game isn't too repetitive and does have moments that split away from just combat or just exploration. Speaking of that, there's a decent exploration element in this game that often is a bit rewarding for little extra tidbits, imagery, and sometimes goodies and hidden weapons. The game has some fun unlockable costumes and weapons.

The story is enjoyable in a B-fare kind of way, and is backed by good music and sound design. While not Akira's best work, the music still holds up well for the title. There are small touches to the game too and details that are appreciated, including each grave stone in the graveyard having a different description on them (and there are many), some small scares that the player may miss if they aren't observant or don't explore a bit. The atmosphere is okay, though the game really isn't scary.

But I didn't hate my time with it, in fact, I would say I enjoyed myself playing it. It's got so many flaws and they're so easy to point out, but despite it all there is an enjoyable game in here. It honestly probably would of been better if it was Silent Hill The Movie: The Game though, as it really does things that just doesn't sit right as a fan of the series. But in its own way, it's an enjoyable B-Movie sort of horror game that has dips into legitimately good moments and ideas.

If you go in expecting some B-Horror fun, as opposed to a Silent Hill game, it's a pretty okay to good game in its own right, just has some flaws, but I wouldn't say the flaws ruin the game and there is some fun and interesting sections to be had as the game goes on. If you go to it for a Silent Hill fix, however, I think you'll be bitterly disappointed. A misguided, but ultimately pretty okay game, that could of been a good game if it wasn't bogged down by a few problems.

reviewText:
As a fan of Silent Hill since the beginning, this title undoes everything that made the series unique and enjoyable. The strong points of the series have always been atmosphere, design, and sheer compelling mystery. Homecoming fails on all of these points.

Firstly, the story, unlike those in previous games, is utterly predictable and tedious. It's straight out of the worst horror movies; every spoken line will seem familiar and you can predict half the scenes and twists before they happen. The stories in the previous games weren't always perfectly written, but they were never this insultingly cliché. There's no mystery, no creeping fear, no unresolved questions.

As for the monsters, they nearly look right for the series, but their behavior is worlds apart. Instead of being willful and mysterious, they're just like the posturing, aggressive beasts you'll find in any other game. That's more a matter of taste, but fighting them is definitely more simplistic than before. When you engage an enemy, you can practically feel the scripting pop into gear; the whole process is nothing but a timing game. Block, button mash, the end. Or, if the monster gets a hit in, enjoy being hit again and again and again as you try to either get back up or get out of the way. It's cheap and nothing but cheap, and not remotely enjoyable. Compounding this fact is that you have only 3 melee weapons that differ in speed and attack pattern, and these qualities stay the same even when you get new weapons (which just replace one of these 3, and play exactly the same).

The puzzles are shockingly simple. The solutions are frequently completely obvious, sometimes even without reading the hint (which is usually posted immediately near the puzzle, and barely obscures the solution if at all). In two cases, object interaction puzzles are actually repeated; one is only slightly different the second time around, but the other one is literally the exact same puzzle with the exact same method of solution! Overall, the puzzles come off like an afterthought, and add nothing to the experience.

If you're looking to extend your Silent Hill experience with Homecoming, forget it. Because it isn't Silent Hill, it is a horror game called Homecoming.

reviewText:
I just finished Homecoming and as much as I love Silent Hill (and I do, Silent Hill 2 is one of my favorite games ever), I simply cannot recommend PC version of this game.

The Good
Visuals: 7/10
Game aged significantly 7 years since its release and let’s face it, it wasn’t an eye candy to begin with. Overall it still looks good. You stop noticing low res textures eventually. Monster design is definitely amazing!

Sound & Music: 7/10
If you have played previous Silent Hill games you’ve come to expect a great soundtrack. All though Akira Yamaoka’s sound is easily recognizable, soundtrack itself is slightly underwhelming. I remember listening Silent Hill 2 soundtrack on a loop for weeks. I don’t feel the same about this one but it has its bright spots. Overall good music and creepy ambient. You can find OST on youtube. It is worth listening to even if you’ve never played the game.

Story: 7/10
Story is full of traditional creepy characters and plot twists. Some of the ideas were not exactly fresh but overall story and characters were pretty interesting.

The BadCombat and controls.
It didn’t bother me that this SH game was more action oriented than previous installments but combat itself was rather frustrating. It felt awkward and slow. I died so many times until I realized that using a knife (the very first weapon) was the way to against most of the enemies. By the end of the game fighting was no longer a challenge. I had so many med kits and health drinks, I didn’t know what to do with them.

Save Points.
There are not that many. Since you die rather often early in the game and game crashes regularly (at least in my experience) replaying the same area over and over again becomes very annoying quickly.

Loading time.
It takes a WHILE to load a new area or a save game (I played it on i7-5820K / 16GB / GTX970). Also, sometimes game just freezes for a few seconds.

The UglyGlitches
There are plenty. To list a few:
Controls are unresponsive during button mashing sequences.
You cannot damage monsters. Only happened once, I wasted all my ammo and died a few times. It was fixed after I restarted the game.
Sound sometimes is coming out of only one speaker and a couple of times audio was out of sync during cut-scenes.
Many people reported glitches with certain puzzles all thought I haven’t experienced any. Crashes
It must have crashed at least 25-30 time during a single playthrough. There was no particular pattern. Sometimes it crashes on startup (Often 2-3 times in a row. If you keep restarting it will launch eventually). Sometimes mid game, sometimes during cut-scenes, sometimes during a loading sequence. Very late in the game it crashed 8 times in a row in the same exact spot. This is when I was ready to give up. I’m glad it didn’t crash 9 times in a row otherwise I would never be able to finish the game :(
None of the solutions I found online helped me (although, I think lowering graphic settings does help in some cases). I tried playing on 2 different PCs, on Win7 and on Win10.

I am glad I finished the game. I enjoyed parts of it but overall it was a very frustrating experience because how bad this port is. In the end it was a sigh of relief rather than satisfaction from a completed game.

If you are a fan of Silent Hill franchise or horror games in general this game is worth playing but you will be better off playing it on a console.

Silent Hill Homecoming:  7/10
Silent Hill Homecoming (Horrible PC Port Edition): 4/10

This game is spooky and terrifying more than just whats in the game.  In the game, the world around you can fragment and break away as the world of silent hill infects everything around the character.  Oddly this game has that effect in real life, making it more than just a horrific game to play, but a horrific experience for everyone in the world even YOU!  *chains rattle

This is a throwback game to survival horror with exploration at its heart.  The world thats made is pretty much free roam to be explored with items to find making it feel a bit like RE1.  When this was released everyone hated it, its competition was Dead Space so thats a tough one to go against without bringing the A game.  This game though does what few games do anymore which is exploration in a world of survival horror, the monsters while not diverse fit the atmosphere including a boss right out of Human Centipede named Asphyxia derived from greek meaning without heartbeat.

Anyone who hated the movie, will hate this game.  Story is similar but vastly different in its approach making it fresh for fans who saw the movie a billion times.  Those who hated the movie should check it out again now to see what a top movie studio can bring to blood guts and gore that they really havent done since if they want something to appreciate.   For survival horror fans who couldnt stomach this game at release its the modern day now so all we get are walking simulators with spooky stuffs.

This game is horrific to look at visually, in all the wrong ways which somehow makes this game even creepier.  Released for Xbox 360 and PS3 using the Havok Engine, which brought us everything from Skyrim to Oblivion and Dark Souls.  Silent Hill comes off looking like some abomination mix of PS2 textures, with PS3 character models for some characters while others are PS2 looking or even PS1 with the fidelity of their textures.  This mashup of quality lends itself actually to Silent Hill, where something is always a bit off.  Something always lurking below the surface, in a good way this bad quality in any other game actually adds to its charm here of being an evil demonic messed up interdimensional crossover crazy kinda world.

The lighting however is pure genius, some of the best ever in gaming for this genre.  The world isnt BLACK like other games to add a fake fear factor.  For many games that is their gimmick a one trick pony of wondering whats outside the dark.  Its a cheap gimmick, and people make that world, they design it for atmosphere and if we cant see it or feel the atmosphere their just wasting their time and ours.  In this game its dim everywhere just right to get a feeling for the world or place you are in, there is a flashlight to further light up areas since its so dim.  Dim means we can see the world its amazing a work of art that way in survival horror design where many games opt to just make everything black.

The gameplay is brutal, playing it on normal isnt bad at all, playing it on hard is doable as well.  Dodge is almost broken but works under very very precise conditions relying on the skill of the player to memorize the moves of a given boss to anticipate them and react.  On hard with bad controls every boss can still be beat with melee.  The controls are as horrific as everything else, there isnt much if any of a tutorial so its just wing it and see what works with different weapons.

Bugs, well this game has em all, from being version 1.0 we bring you random crashes and bugs galore.  The game will freeze erratically at times then magically unfreeze.  Oddly many of these glitches somehow also add to how the game infects your computer and its own engine.  The world of silent hill and how it wants to ruin everything can not be contained!  None of these are gamebreaking, there are save spots so if it crashes no big loss.

reviewText:
A terrible port of a mediocre horror game that marked the moment Silent Hill truly jumped the shark as a franchise.

While a few faint glimmers of hope remain in the music and boss design, the overall mood and feel of the game is nothing like classic Silent Hill games and it completely fails to create any sort of tension or compelling narrative. A greater emphasis on combat removes the horror from the equation, and the combat itself is awkward and jittery. Not to mention, the starting knife attacks so quickly it can stunlock almost every enemy in the game and makes every other melee weapon useless.

And this is all assuming you can actually get it running. Especially on newer systems, you're likely not to be able to launch the game at all without some fiddling. And if you do, expect a lack of video options and weird performance issues or visual glitches all around, as well as frequent crashes. It's a messy version of a game that was already a mess, and yet somehow they still feel fine charging $40 for it.

If you're eyeing this one during a sale in hopes of one last little gasp of Silent Hill to satisfy your craving, just don't. You'd be wasting your money and your time on a game that is an amateurish, embarrassing shadow of those that came before it. It's not scary, it's not fun, and it's not interesting or well-written, failing to give any reason to justify its existence.

The game itself is a decent game, although it isn't an original story, and many of the monsters are also taken from other silent hill games, it is still a fun game. The main reason this game sucks however is that whoever ported this to the PC deserves to get slapped. Just another buggy piece of junk.

Once I got through the usual black screen startup inherent to a lot of rushed PC games, I had to figure out why the game was running on such a low (often stuttering) framerate on my usually quite decent hardware (core i5 + gtx 770), but after tinkering few minutes with some settings in the config files and trying to overload vsync in nvidia control panel (turning it off gave me terrible screen tearing, which was a pretty bad sign considering my hardware and the game graphics), I got to the conclusion that the game was just performing the best it could and that its coding was just a mess... of course this was confirmed when I encountered ridiculous 5/10 seconds freezes after some cutscenes. The whole thing was starting to make me quite uneasy as save points in this game are set way too far appart, but more on that soon!

Anyway, despite the terrible performance, I still wanted to give it a shot, as I'm a big amateur of the Silent Hill series and actually owned the same game on X360, but never got much far due to the utter annoyance of the combat system in hard difficulty and one awful freeze that made me lost one hour of boring gameplay. But this time I was determined to go through with it, thinking a pretty average game with Akira Yamaoka's music might at least give me a bit of pleasure.

So there i was, wasting another time tediously running around on some cheap scavenger hunt from corridor to corridor in what appears to be an even more cheap knock off of a Silent Hill game, which quickly throws a bunch of cliches from Silent Hill 2  at you without even trying to have its own identity. It's really quite impressive how bad Double Helix was at this, but hardly surprising if you look at their other games or even at the ones from their former companies (nothing really good appart from a bunch of games in the 90's). How they got this gig is mind-boggling and just shows how Konami execs have become out of touch this last decade to the point of trusting these hacks with one of their most emblematic franchise. It's kind of sad from a company that most definitely was at the top of its game from the 8bit to the PS2 era (one of my best gaming memories as a kid where on their SNES games. still remember how seeing their logo screen popping up would instantly reassure me that I was in for some quality gaming time).

But I disgress... Remember what I said about those save points being way too far appart for a buggy game like this? Right after the first level of the game, you get into a really tedious part of the game, which pretty much consists of running around way too much in different parts of the town. I only had one save point in the beginning, but then I got to almost fully explore a house, picked up quite a bunch of stuff, got to explore the first part of a cemetery only to have to backtrack quite far, because I didn't see the right climbing path the first time around. And then, just before I finally got to the next save point, BAM! got accidentely ALT-TABed out of the game, which of course crashed when I tried to get back in it! Almost made me smile... Almost :p. Anyway, I was just looking for a good reason to put this game down early (and forever. this time) and it looks like it made me a favor by collapsing from the weight of its own mediocrity after a mere 1 hour of gameplay.

So there you have it. Think twice before buying this terrible port. Even if you actually remotely enjoyed it on consoles, you're probably going to have a bad time. Besides, there are so much better games like this one to try (hell, even a small indie game like Lone Survivor gets it more). In the meanwhile Konami might pull their head out of their ♥♥♥♥ and redeem themselves by releasing the 4 earliest Silent Hill games on Steam. Hopefully it'll happen before they cut their veins open, while ingesting pachinko balls and frenetically playing DDR until they die while trying to figure out how they can revive" another franchise. Yeah... this must how they've been making their decisions lately."

reviewText:
This was my first Silent Hill game and my second Silent Hill experience (after the really good movie). In this game, you arrive in a small town to discover that almost everyone disappeared. It's up to you to discover what happened in Shepherd's Glen. The interesting story is part of the reason why I bought this game.

If you liked Alan Wake, you'll like this game. It's also a 3rd person horror game and it's almost as scary. I would say it's more gore than scary most of the time but the atmosphere is still really good. As for the gameplay,  you discover many weapons (melee or ranged) throughout the game but the ammos are limited so it's up to the player to use them wisely !

It's not really long but I would say it's adequate for this kind of game. It took me about 7-8 hours to finish. It's longer than most of the horror games nowadays.

As for the PC port, I read so many bad reviews that I was wondering if it would run on my computer. Finally, it worked without any problem for most of the game. I did NOT encounter any crash but at the end of the game, the game 'freezed' before saving for about 20-30 seconds. Pretty annoying but it's nothing game-breaking. There's also a puzzle at the beginning of the game (Wires) that did not work at all since i couldn't click on something else with my mouse. I had to plug a controller and then unplug it to finally be able to select the next wire. That was the worst bug I saw in this game.

In conclusion, buy this game if you love horror games and don't mind about some bugs from the PC port (also considering that it's the only Silent Hill game on Steam, there's not much to complaint about.. at least we have this one)

reviewText:
I have played this game when I have been offline so my hours played do not reflect the real time I have invested in the game.

Beginning with story: Not engrossing enough to keep you gripped. You will typically be able to predict what is coming next.

The characters are wrote in such a way that they lack depth and it is hard to form a bond with them.

Gameplay: Punishing, almost arcade-style. You will die frequently as the enemies are scripted to pummel you with quicker attack speeds and wider attack range than you can achieve. You will find yourself spamming the dodge-uppercut move hoping for a lucky shot.

The puzzle sections are good, not great. They offer subtle aids to help you complete them, but the reward for your endeavour is not always felt.

The saving mechanic is flawed mainly because the save points are placed at random points, forcing you to rely on checkpoints. Some checkpoints are poorly done as they force you to watch cutscenes again and again that you can not skip.

Software: The software crashes at random points in the game. I don't claim to have the best gaming pc, but I have researched that even high spec pcs suffer from the random bugs infesting the software.

Verdict: This game has about 5% of the spirit of Silent Hill, leaving much to be desired. Unless you are a diehard who must own everything Silent Hill, avoid this one and research other horror titles to spend your cash on.

I got this as a gift a long time ago, and I played through it while streaming for an audience. Although I'd love to say I like receiving gifts, I would have much rather the person who gave this to me kept his money.

The writing is awful, as well, and this game tries way too hard to fit in with the series. The studio behind this project did go forward to make much better Silent Hill games, but shamefully, Homecoming is the only one of the newest games to get a PC Port.

If you don't have a console, stick with the older games or pick up a different series. If you do have a console, ignore Homecoming completely and get Shattered Memories or Downpour.

reviewText:
As a gamer, I go for the story first and the game second. The story of 'Silent Hill: Homecoming' left me cold. Very cold. It didn't really feel like a Silent Hill game at all. It was more like the movie (which I hated, btw).

While the mist, the otherworld and most of the monsters fit into the series quite nicely, the main characters and the bosses however did not. I know they wanted it to be more like in the movie, and some of you might actually like that. The movie is really popular after all.

The controls are simple, battle works fine, but sometimes when attacked by a feral my game glitched and I couldn't fight it off, resulting in game over. Let's talk about puzzles. I like puzzles. Me and my SO have spent days on the puzzles of SH2, 3 and 4, but not homecoming. Not because the puzzles were bad, oh no. Most of the puzzles are the usual find item to go forward, with a few delicious exceptions. I particularly enjoyed the otherworld house. Music and themes fit nicely with the slightly out of focus and hopeless genre, sounds the enemies make are panic-inducing at times (especially the Needler, who the hell came up with that??), and voice acting, while a bit stiff, is way better than in a certain previous title.

It is hard for me to say that the game is bad, at least from the perspective of a devout fan, but I feel like I absolutely have to. I did not like this game. Silent Hill fan? You should try this game. Maybe even buy it, if you can get it for less than 15€.

There's one good thing about it though: Unlockable Pyramid Head Helmet.

reviewText:
Notice: I ran into a game-breaking issue two hours into the game. By that point I was so let down by my experience that I didn't bother trying to fix the problem. This review is based off of my experience in those two hours.

Gods, what a let down. I'm glad I got this game on sale, or else I'd be spitting hellfire right now. Anyways. On to my grievances.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=405044752
Not once was I ever scared in my two hours of Homecoming, be it by the weakly designed monsters or the thinly veiled atmosphere. And I even tried to become immersed, playing completely in the dark with headphones and no other distractions. The characters are bland, the scares amateur and the whole game experience disappointing. Even the music is forgettable and boring.

The biggest problem I have with this game however, is Pyramid Head's brief (and anticlimactic) appearance.

I mean, it's entirely pointless. PH is a Silent Hill 2 exclusive monster for canonical reasons, him being a hallucination as a part of James Sunderland's guilt-ridden psyche. PH showing up randomly for no damn reason is entirely pointless and completely shatters the thin crust of immersion I managed to accumulate from this sad drooling mess of a game. It's one of the biggest offences of non sexual fanservice I have ever seen, obviously done purely out of desperation to connect this game with its far superior predecessors. Also what the ♥♥♥♥ is Robbie doing in the game? Homecoming doesn't even take place in Silent Hill!

Also the 'other world' was introduced FAR too early in the game. What made the 'other world' so terrifying in earlier games was that it was introduced later on, after the player had built up a hefty load of unease and tension. You can't just slam your ace into your audience's faces right off the bat like that.

What this game needed was uniqueness. If it had been released separately, as its own game without 'Silent Hill' in the title then it would have been a vaguely decent standalone horror title. Sure it still would probably have tanked, but at least it wouldn't have put a massive smear onto the name of a legendary series.

Don't let the Silent Hill in the name fool you. This game isn't anything special, like the original games were. It's just a sad attempt to cash in on the dying franchise. I'd close this with a comment about looking forwards to Silent Hills but, well. We all know the fate of P.T by now. Rest in peace, you terrifying gem.

Notice: I ran into a game-breaking issue two hours into the game. By that point I was so let down by my experience that I didn't bother trying to fix the problem. This review is based off of my experience in those two hours.

Gods, what a let down. I'm glad I got this game on sale, or else I'd be spitting hellfire right now. Anyways. On to my grievances.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=405044752
Not once was I ever scared in my two hours of Homecoming, be it by the weakly designed monsters or the thinly veiled atmosphere. And I even tried to become immersed, playing completely in the dark with headphones and no other distractions. The characters are bland, the scares amateur and the whole game experience disappointing. Even the music is forgettable and boring.

The biggest problem I have with this game however, is Pyramid Head's brief (and anticlimactic) appearance.

I mean, it's entirely pointless. PH is a Silent Hill 2 exclusive monster for canonical reasons, him being a hallucination as a part of James Sunderland's guilt-ridden psyche. PH showing up randomly for no damn reason is entirely pointless and completely shatters the thin crust of immersion I managed to accumulate from this sad drooling mess of a game. It's one of the biggest offences of non sexual fanservice I have ever seen, obviously done purely out of desperation to connect this game with its far superior predecessors. Also what the ♥♥♥♥ is Robbie doing in the game? Homecoming doesn't even take place in Silent Hill!

Also the 'other world' was introduced FAR too early in the game. What made the 'other world' so terrifying in earlier games was that it was introduced later on, after the player had built up a hefty load of unease and tension. You can't just slam your ace into your audience's faces right off the bat like that.

What this game needed was uniqueness. If it had been released separately, as its own game without 'Silent Hill' in the title then it would have been a vaguely decent standalone horror title. Sure it still would probably have tanked, but at least it wouldn't have put a massive smear onto the name of a legendary series.

Don't let the Silent Hill in the name fool you. This game isn't anything special, like the original games were. It's just a sad attempt to cash in on the dying franchise. I'd close this with a comment about looking forwards to Silent Hills but, well. We all know the fate of P.T by now. Rest in peace, you terrifying gem.

reviewText:
Same as (almost) every Silent Hill game.

Atmosphere and eeriness that impress and immerse most horror enthusiasts, through both sound design and visuals. Combat mechanics that will leave you in awe of how poorly executed the gameplay side (always) is.

If you do intend to go through the game, look up each of the monsters weaknesses online.
There are a series of monster counters that are arbitrary, unobvious, but necessary to succeed in fights. If you don't know these, you risk losing 1-3+ health items per engagement, which can force you to restart the game from the beginning if you run out before a dangerous part.

For example, if you're the sort who thinks a massive fireaxe would be a good counter against a slowly and steadily advancing undead nurse with a knife, you're already dead after being locked down into an unbreakable slicing and stabbing combo that prevents you from even opening the weapon screen, let alone attacking or dodging. And you can face up to 3 Nurses in one engagement.

=== Bad PC Port Warnings ===

Control CFG: Your controls may glitch back to default each time you load a save game. Only solution is to close the game and re-open it. If it keeps happening, you have to go into the game's binding cfgs and manually set both controller type and key for EVERY binding. Curiously this only seems to happen with the Keyboard/Mouse side of the controls.

Minimize/Maximize: Do you use your computer for anything other than gaming?
Well, it will probably have to be put on hold. If you minimize the game, it'll probably crash the next time you open it.

Minimap: A chunk of the bottom may be cut out if you play on higher resolutions. If so, you will have to use the Zoom function to figure out where you are.

Freezing: You may experience common, random freezes that last just long enough to convince you the game has perma-froze, and short enough to make sure you catch that quivering twitching knife or scythe in the face. God save you if it happens in the middle of a one-hit-kill-quick-time sequence.

=== In Summary ===

Exactly what you would expect when a Japanese company turns over a famous franchise to a Western company. If you can endure combat that is repeatedly unexplained, unfair, and unpolished, you will enjoy atmosphere that is creepy, eerie, and engaging. The atmosphere is as good as the gameplay is bad.

reviewText:
Be very wary and steer clear of this port. Just buy it on consoles if you have the chance.

Pros:
+ Decent Graphics at the time of release
+ Oppressive but effective atmosphere
+ Boss designs are very distrubing yet creative
+ Soundtrack is mesmerizing

Cons:
- Very annoying audio issues where a majority of the audio will output through one speaker/earphone. No way to fix it.
- Graphical inconsistencies with minor pop-in.
- Controls are unresponsive or fail to display command keys if they are rebinded.
- No achievement support, unlike the Xbox 360 version.
- Game is locked at 30FPS with no way to unlock to 60FPS. There is no community support on the game.
- Game is very short, ranging from 4-8 hours depending if you do not get stuck on its abyssmal level designs.
- Frequent crashing, especially if changing settings or simply just saving the game state.
- Oddly, the game is very combat oriented, which is unusual for a Silent Hill game, but its not a deal breaker, per se.
- NPC animations and textures are very stiff and lacking.
-Sadly, the game is just a rehash of the SIlent Hill movie and Silent Hill 2 combined, but not always in the right ways.

reviewText:
While every aspect of this game isn’t the worst that Konami has ever offered.  The continued sale of this unsupported and fundamentally flawed product at 39.99 can only serve to polarize unwitting purchasers against the publisher and developer alike.

I originally bought this title as part of a sale in 2011.  As a huge fan of the first 3 silent titles I had high hopes despite mixed reviews.  However, I immediately regretted my decision. The port was so buggy I was unable to progress more than a few minutes into the game.  This game sat dormant within my library for 5 years with only 6 minutes of play until Steam’s revised return policy gave me a chance to right my mistake.  Sadly, steam did not grant my refund, 5 years is a long time, so half hoping to work myself into tizzy I reinstalled.  Well it worked….kind of.  Whether the result of a patch or my new hardware I was able to complete the game, though at times wised I hadn’t.

Silent hill homecoming features the series trademark moody, misty, and mysterious environments.  The game play is built around over the shoulder 3rd person combat, typical fetch quest, puzzles, and even a few undercooked metroidvainia style elements.  However, depth clearly wasn’t a design driver.  The fetch quests are simple, and due to relatively barren environments it doesn’t take to long to figure out what goes to what.  Next, Homecoming is missing legacy features like combine item, and inventory item examination thus removing further depth from this installment of the franchise.  But don’t despair, with the exception of a few mid game riddles, Homecoming treats you to puzzles like that slide puzzle at your dentist office or there own R rated version of the baby shape game.

The combat system is almost a bright spot.  The Combat utilizes several melee weapon classes and small arms featuring a relatively linear progression in reach and damage.  While the ranged combat is what you might expect from a 3rd person shooter, the melee combat is more developed than any previous SH title.  Players can dodge attacks, counter, block, heavy attack, execute finishers, and even combo in game.  Sounds pretty sweet right, and it would be if it wasn’t for your ability to crit-lock nearly all enemies, broken quick time events, and unfriendly camera angles.  Your inventory is also oddly limited.  For despite Alex’s ability to carry a knife, pipe, axe, shotgun, pistol, and rifle your character can’t seem to find more than a handful of space for ammo, making the survival horror staple of stockpiling resources a no go.

One thing I did like was Homecomings story and voice work.  The campaigns premise while unoriginal just works, and late game plot reveals do a great job making sense of memory flashes and found tokens.  In addition I found myself constantly guessing at who Alex is.  Is he crazy, already dead, or a resident of otherworld like Lisa from first Silent Hill.  Hell, for half the game I was pretty sure Alex was an imaginary friend.  Despite these great story elements Homecoming features some terribly developed characters, none of whom seem to find perpetual mist, infrastructure ending sink holes, or an army of other worldly demons all that odd.  While the game cleans this up late game in a Shamalan style twist, it does so at the cost of creating plot holes you could drive a bus through.

Graphically the game might be best described a barren, even for a port.  A lot of environmental objects are use repeatedly but sparingly.  The textures also are so underwhelming you might not realize Alex’s jacket is desert-camo and not desert tan.  The character models and monsters however are greatly detailed and feel a bit out of place in the low poly count world.

In terms of replay value Silent Hill Homecoming features 4 different endings based on three critical decision events distributed evenly throughout the campaign.  Since we got one ending, and one bonus costume out of our 11 hour campaign pass we’re confident there is a lot of game play left for the masochist that needs to see it all, but most of you should just Youtube them instead.  With the exception maybe of running about town bashing monsters wondering what could have been we can’t suggest buying.

Worst of all the game has a tendency to crash and at a minimum freezes for sometimes 30seconds at a time making it one of the least stable games in my collection.  We try to keep our reviews free of outrage.  Others have done it first and better, but even I found it difficult to maintain an objective tone while evaluating this title.  We suggest you don’t buy at any price point.  As always I hope this review has informed your purchase. Be well.

-Bandersuke
